Subjective: Dizziness for 3 days, onset upon waking. Sensation of room spinning (vertigo), with some light-headedness. Worse with head movements; better when sitting still. Associated with mild nausea and transient palpitations during episodes. Interferes with daily activities. No vomiting, headache, hearing loss, tinnitus, speech difficulty, or fainting. No focal weakness. Recent mild cold. No prolonged bed rest. Social: No smoking, alcohol, or drug use. Request: Wants to know cause and get rid of dizziness; fears a brain tumor like a friend had.
Objective: Vitals: BP 110/70, HR 62. Neuro Exam: Cranial nerves intact. Motor strength 5/5 and symmetric throughout. Cerebellar testing normal, including finger-to-nose, Romberg, and gait/tandem gait. Vestibular Exam: Smooth pursuit intact. Head Impulse Test (HIT) negative bilaterally. Dix-Hallpike maneuver positive, provoking vertigo, nausea, and visible nystagmus; symptoms more intense on one side.
Assessment: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV). Brain tumor ruled out.
Plan:
1. Reassurance provided; explained BPPV pathophysiology (vestibular crystals). 
2. Epley maneuver performed in-office. 
3. Provided instructions for home Epley maneuver via patient education website (thuisarts.nl). 
4. No medications prescribed. 
5. Follow up if symptoms do not improve or worsen.
